title: Fiji's Sam Matavesi grew up in Cornwall and is preparing to shock Wales in the Rugby World Cup
text:
He is the Fijian hooker with the Cornish accent who now is ready for a shot at Wales at the World Cup.

Sam Matavesi has many people to thank for being in Japan for this tournament. Most of all his father, Sireli, who is the reason while Sam might look like a big, beaming Pacific Islander, he sounds like a Wurzel.

‘My dad was one of the first foreign players to come to England,’ Matavesi tells Sportsmail. He came over for the Fiji Barbarians in the late 1980s, and they played a World tour which finished in Cornwall.

Sam Matavesi (third left) is hoping to help spring a shock upset over Wales at the World Cup

‘They played against Camborne and Redruth when those teams were in the top leagues. He went back to Fiji and got an offer to go to Cornwall again.

‘So he went from being a coconut farmer in Fiji to working in Cornwall’s tin mines!

‘That was in 1987 - and he has been there ever since. He then had three kids with mum - three boys - me and Josh and one more Joel as well.’

Two of those brothers are here in Japan representing Fiji at the World Cup - Sam, now 27, plays in the front row, and 29-year-old Josh is a fly-half.

And Matavesi Jnr is hugely proud to play for the land of his father and his upbringing.

‘When you grow up in Cornwall you are clearly English but massively Cornish too,’ he added.

‘You represent Cornwall, where we’re from, and obviously Fiji now too.

‘It’s been a long time out here. I’m missing my family, but it’s worth it.

‘Hopefully it’s not once in a lifetime, but if it is you want to make the most of the opportunity. To represent my country at a World Cup is amazing.

The 27-year-old grew up in Cornwall after his father moved to England in the 1980s

‘At the last World Cup I watched three of the games - so to be here four years on is special.

‘I went to England v Fiji at Twickenham, then Fiji’s Wales and Australia games in Cardiff - so that was three of the four. It’s really special.’ Matavesi owes this to the Navy too. His day job is as a supply chain logistician at the Royal Naval Air Station in Culdrose near Helston.

‘Luckily they have let me play in this World Cup - otherwise I’d be on a ship somewhere!’ Matavesi smiles.

‘I’ve been in the Navy for four years. On the air station I’m part of the team that supports the aircraft. That could be from spares it needs, to fuel, to anything.

‘I would be working every day if I wasn’t here. I should be at sea right now!’ But now Matavesi is in at the deep end at the World Cup, with Wales up next on Wednesday.

Sam is the brother of Josh Matavesi, who plays as the fly half for the Fiji national team

It has been a topsy-turvy tournament for Fiji where they have lost to unfancied Uruguay, and angry Australia but beat Georgia 45-10 on Thursday to set themselves up for a charge at Warren Gatland’s side.

And having grown up in England, Matavesi cannot wait.

‘I’ve watched lots of England v Wales games in the Six Nations over the years.’ he said.

‘They are a massive team, and it’s going to be a massive test for us. If we can build Georgia it’s going to be a good game.

Fiji got their World Cup campaign back on track after a thumping win over Georgia in Pool D

‘Wales are so clinical and good at squeezing teams and making them play.

‘That’s international rugby. They’re one of the best teams in the world. Even though Georgia was good for us, and it was good, we’ve got to up it a lot next week if we want to perform against Wales.

‘We have to respect them, but as Fijians we have to show what we can do.

‘When we are confident and happy it works. We need to keep that the same.

‘Fiji beat Wales at the World Cup in 2007. I watched that - who knows eh?’
description: WILL KELLEHER IN OTSU EXCLUSIVE: Sam Matavesi is the Fijian hooker with the Cornish accent who now is ready for a shot at Wales at the Rugby World Cup in Japan.
authors: Will Kelleher For The Daily Mail
